items.title: HTML Custom Elements which inherit from an existing element don't instantiate correctly when used in HTML templates

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

items.body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
Not sure, whatever handles populating HTML templates.

### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è-->
No idea, sorry.


### Description

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è-->
A great example is x-frame-bypass, and this confused user in particular:

https://github.com/niutech/x-frame-bypass/issues/22

x-frame-bypass is a custom element that inherits from iframe and does some... interesting things. Regardless, if you drop it into angular and attempt to use it in an HTML template, it's clear a normal iframe gets created despite the output HTML being correct. If you manually use element.innerHTML to inject the custom element it works properly.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-ztlius

Top frame is added with HTML templates, bottom with innerHtml injection. Both tags should function identically.

## üî• Exception or Error
Placing breakpoints in the constructor of the x-frame-bypass class will confirm it is only instantiated for the bottom frame. It looks like the top frame is being instantiated as a normal iframe.

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**
Angular CLI: 11.1.4
Node: 14.16.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.1.2
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1101.4
@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1101.4
@angular-devkit/core            11.1.4
@angular-devkit/schematics      11.1.4
@angular/cdk                    11.2.0
@angular/cli                    11.1.4
@angular/material               11.2.0
@schematics/angular             11.1.4
@schematics/update              0.1101.4
rxjs                            6.6.3
typescript                      4.1.5

Also, reproduces in stackblitz which I assume is the latest and greatest?

**Anything else relevant?**
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èIs this a browser specific issue? If so, please specify the browser and version. -->

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èDo any of these matter: operating system, IDE, package manager, HTTP server, ...? If so, please mention it below. -->
Related bug report on x-frame-bypass: https://github.com/niutech/x-frame-bypass/issues/22 (Assuming the reporter confirm my suspicions, at least.)

items.title: Angular 10.2.4 xi18n with --ivy: equiv-text contains wrong value when using CRLF line endings

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

items.body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Probably @angular/cli @angular/compiler @angular/localize ### Is this a regression? Similar bugs were already fixed multiple times #38694 #38711 #39654 ### Description From what I've gathered from the other bugs when you have Windows line endings CRLF the source maps only generate one character for it, which causes the source maps to become misaligned. This causes the `equiv-text` to contain the wrong value: ```

Test asdf

``` Becomes **equiv-text="y-asdf"**: ``` Test asdf src/app/app.component.html 13 ``` In the latest Angular 11 version this is fixed, but since Angular 10 is LTS I really hope you will fix this for the older version as well. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/stefan-schweiger/angular-10-xi18n-crlf-bug You need to make sure to check out the project with CRLF line endings (or format the files yourself). Then just run `ng xi18n --output-path src/locale --ivy` ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 10.2.4 (10.2.3 for cli)

items.title: Consider supporting `styles` and `styleUrls` defined with `as const` in different buildable units

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Issue that requests a new feature

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

items.body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package

@angular/compiler

### Description
Ivy compiler requires all `@Component` metadata to be resolved statically. So generally it's not possible to declare an array of styles of style URLs in a different buildable units and use them in the current one, since the actual values would not be available in D.TS files (only corresponding type declarations). However declaring such arrays with `as const` modifier pulls the value into D.TS files and Ivy compiler can technically leverage this information:

In TS:
```
const styles = ['margin: 0px', 'padding: 0px'] as const;
const styleUrls = ['./style-a.css', './style-b.css'] as const;
```

Corresponding D.TS:
```
declare const styles: readonly ["margin: 0px", "padding: 0px"];
declare const styleUrls: readonly ["./style-a.css", "./style-b.css"];
```

(same example in [TypeScript playground](https://www.typescriptlang.org/play?ssl=3&ssc=63&pln=2&pc=1#code/MYewdgzgLgBFCmBbADgGwIYJgXhgcnQCNg8BuAKFElmgE9V4IcYBtPRdAJwHMBLMAFwwADMgAeeADT5k6ACZz+3IaIkBdGOiZVoFHTSj14AVU6omuNgDoA9HQYBadFeAQIU-LfvwHhF27wNLRh9CiA))

Currently the compiler's static evaluation can understand string literal types, but not tuple types.

labels.name: comp: docs

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

items.body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

In "Reusable Animations" one should mention the most simple way of reusing identical animation in multiple components:
Exctract the trigger/transition as `const` and use this in all components. This is probably resolving many developers needs with less overhead than the documented `useAnimation` way.

See e.g. https://stackoverflow.com/a/39463660/2544163


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### What's the affected URL?**
https://angular.io/guide/reusable-animations

items.title: Select dropdowns with ngValue binding perform far worse than expected

labels.name: P4
labels.description: Low-priority issue that needs to be resolved

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

items.body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package @angular/forms

### Is this a regression?

Regression from AngularJS.

### Description

I noticed that there was a noticeable delay when populating a select dropdown with several hundred+ items using an ngValue binding, which does not occur with other frameworks (I also tested AngularJS and Svelte). Digging into the Angular code it turns out that the `_compareWith` function in select_control_value_accessor.ts is being called an absurdly high number of times.

I expected that this function would just be called no more than once for each item in the dropdown (i.e. loop through the options until a match is found). However, it is actually called exponentially more. E.g. for a dropdown with 1000 items and the 500th item bound to the ngModel, the function is called 501,001 times. If there are 3000 items in the dropdown and the 1500th item is selected, the `_compareWith` function is called 1,002,501 times. It gets even worse if an option nearer the end of the list is selected.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-select-performance?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts

Note that I added a custom `compareWith` method in this example to log how many times it is called, but the performance is just as bad with the default internal comparison method.

I think the problem stems from Angular's `SelectControlValueAccessor.writeValue()` method being called over and over for each individual option element that is rendered, rather than once after all the options are rendered.

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:** 11.2.6

**Anything else relevant?**
This is especially problematic for our users with slower mobile devices.

items.title: linker: JIT compilation of `ngDeclareComponent` does not handle `components` array

labels.name: P2
labels.description: High priority issue that should be resolved as soon as possible

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

items.body: PR #41104 split the list of used directives into two arrays `directives` and `components`, but the JIT side was not updated. This may result in incomplete component definitions at runtime when the partial declaration is JIT compiled.

items.title: <ng-template> with [ngIf] does not render SVG content

labels.name: P4

milestone.title: Backlog

items.body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Probably @angular/core ? ### Is this a regression? Don't know ### Description When using an `` in the non-asterisk longhand form to render SVG fragments, neither the main template nor the else template are rendered: ```html // component test=true; // template // rendered output ``` Note that using `` with the structural `*ngIf` form does work: ```html ``` Given other issues I've had with svg, I've tried both with and without `svg:` namespace prefixes on the child svg elements. Seems to exhibit the same behaviour in both cases. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-kpeerk ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Node: 14.15.5
